recordings.loc: Beckford's Tower, Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Singing from a wire. Continuation from XC562344. From 0:57 another Whitethroat calls nearby. The bird would sing for a while from one place and then move to another; at the end it sings from a different perch. 


There is some mimicry here: at 0:07 a Goldfinch is imitated and at 1:39.2 it includes a copy of a long-tailed tit call. This species can also be heard in the background and the Whitethroat may have heard this bird. The sound is repeated at 2:03.6, 2:24.2 and 2:31.0 There is also possible mimicry of a Robin at 1:40.7 and 2:21.8. 

EQ adjusted below 2500 Hz to remove a little nearby vehicle noise.

You may find the time references do not accurately point to the actual referred times, as discussed in [Forum topic 25398](https://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/25398).

recordings.loc: Beckford's Tower, Bath, Bath and North East Somerset, England
recordings.rmk:
Singing from a wire. Contains mimicry of a Swallow call at 0:59.75, 1:04.1 and 1:12.3. Recorded on a fine morning with an Olympus Ls12 and Sennheiser ME66. EQ adjusted below 1200 Hz to remove some distant road and light handling noise. I continued recording with XC562345 which is of the same bird.

You may find the time references do not accurately point to the actual referred times, as discussed in [Forum topic 25398](https://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/25398).
habitat: wet meadow

recordings.rmk:
Nice minmicry of at least the following species:
Bonelli's warbler, 
Eurasian Oystercatcher, 
Common Swift, 
Barn Swallow, 
Blue Tit, 
Great Tit, 
Carrion Crow, 
Yellow wagtail, 
White Wagtail, 
Little Ringed Plover 
and in the beginning a possible Short-toed Lark

**Comments**: None.

**Recording modifications**: HPF 1000 Hz, 6 dB; normalised peak amplitude to -3.0 dB. Modified using Audacity. Recorded using Olympus LS-P1.

**Habitat (inc. vegetation and level)**: Shrubbery on dunes by the coast.

**Behaviour**: Bird singing perched on a shrub.

**Sex (with ID cues)**: Male, clear grey head.

**Weather and other conditions**: Cloudy and windy morning. 

**Comments on other birds**: Common linnet at the beginning of the recording.

**Comments**: None.

**Recording modifications**: HPF 1500 Hz, 12 dB; normalised peak amplitude to -3.0 dB. Modified using Audacity. Recorded using Olympus LS-P1.

**Habitat (inc. vegetation and level)**: Coastal fields near a dune system. Trees on the side of a local road. 

**Behaviour**: Bird singing in flight. Taking wing from a tree.

**Sex (with ID cues)**: Male; based on the presence of grey head. 

**Weather and other conditions**: Sunny and windy morning. 

**Comments on other birds**: None.

In a dense bramble bush.

recordings.loc: Spurn Point, East Riding of Yorkshire, England
recordings.file-name: XC475753-mimetic song from a perched male Common Whitethroat Spurn Point Yorks 18th May 2019_HH.mp3
recordings.rmk: Very mimetic song from a perched Common Whitethroat, including mimicry of such species as Common Redshank, Herring Gull, Common Ringed Plover, Dunlin, Yellow Wagtail, Sandwich Tern and Curlew. Given that the bird was holding territory adjacent to habitat where all of these (bar perhaps the wagtail in terms of breeding, at least) would be common in season, one must wonder if it learned these imitations this spring in the Spurn area? High pass filter applied below 1kHz.

recordings.file-name: XC475510-LS102518 Grasmus song A Sprinkhaanrietzanger D.mp3

recordings.rmk: The last song strophe is made in song flight and starts with imitations of meadow pipit and linnet.

Classical location of a row of bushes and lower oak trees amidst open land.

recordings.file-name: XC473372-mimetic song from a perched male Common Whitethroat near Whitehaven Cumbria 11th May 2019_HH_1.mp3
recordings.rmk: While I am familiar with mimicry being given by Common Whitethroats during their 'ecstatic' song in song flights, and would expect any bout of song flight to include this, I don't know if I had heard such a mimetic song from a perched bird before, and persistently so as well. Includes mimicry of Great Tit, European Goldfinch, Lesser Redpoll, Eurasian Reed Warbler, Sandwich Tern and others. High pass filter applied below 1kHz.

recordings.file-name: XC420477-scolding calls from a pair of Common Whitethroats plus flight calls from a flock of Common Starlings Power Head 12th June 2018_HH_.mp3
recordings.rmk: Some scolding calls from a pair of Common Whitethroats, then the almost deafening cacophony from a flock of over 200 Common Starlings as they flew by before the Common Whitethroats became audible again. I left shortly afterwards, in case I was the cause for the pair's alarm, though I can't exclude some other cause.

recordings.file-name: XC412788-Common Whitethroat crystallised song Inch 28th April 2018_HH_1.mp3
recordings.rmk: Apparent crystallised song, recording unfiltered. Responded to 'unintentional playback' of a recording I'd made earlier of the same bird giving a less crystallised song, which I stopped playing immediately once I realised that the bird responded (had listened just to see how the sound came out). This recording was made a little while afterwards, but I can't be sure that it wasn't still acting in response to the stimulus.

Recorded from webcam Beaver (Kobras), Lümanda vald, Saaremaa, Estonia.
Recorded from webcam Beaver (Kobras), Lümanda vald, Saaremaa, Estonia.
Recorded from webcam Beaver (Kobras), Lümanda vald, Saaremaa, Estonia.

Clearly mimics Olive/Blue-cheeked Bee-eater (Merops superciliosus/persicus) at 03:43 and European Bee-eater (Merops apiaster) at 03:57, which would indicate that it may be capable of mimicking bird sounds it's heard in its wintering area in Africa.

On the other hand, it seems to mimic either a Marsh warbler (Acrocephalus palustris) or the African birds the Marsh warbler is mimicking at 05:47, 06:23, 06:56, 07:14, 00:38, 02:06. The Marsh warbler in turn, commonly mimicks both European and Olive/Blue-cheeked Bee-eater, compare [Marsh warbler with mimicry of African birds](http://www.xeno-canto.org/set/3341).

Is this first hand mimicry of African birds or second hand mimicry of African birds via the Marsh warbler? I don't really expect anyone to have an answer to that question, but it may start an interesting discussion.

What may be mimicry of a similar type by another Sylvia can be heard in XC385725.

Kiesgrube Thaining (near  Vilgertshofen),  Landsberg/Lech, Oberbayern, Bayern
recordings.rmk:
this bird couldn't stop singing while I watched the ground. For me the numerous variations of its phrases are very interesting. Whitethroats are rare in our area, I heard this species first time this year, may be its was passing through.
Same bird as in XC327196, XC316100,  XC316103,  XC316106, XC316107, XC316132

recordings.loc: Ryedale District (near  Helperthorpe), North Yorkshire, England
recordings.rmk: Whitethroat call ... not filtered ... parabolic ... background noise ...
Immitations of European Bee-eater at 00:18, 00:47, 00:59 and 01:12, European Green Woodpecker at 01:16 and 01:38 and Common Nightingale at 01:21.
Alarm calls switching to song from a bird in a thick bush next to a field.
Song from the top of a tree in an open field. At 0:40 song in flight. Probably the same bird as in XC289803.
Song with some mimicry from a thick bush in an open field.
Song duel between two neighbours in the bushes close to the seashore.

Regular (00:15.8, 00:50.5, 01:52.4, 02:45.0, 03:13.7, 07:50.1, 08:21.0 and fainter at 04:13.2, 04:42.2) and extended (00:00.0, 01:13.8, 03:08.0, 03:19.4, 07:04.9, 08:04.4) song versions. In the extended song versions, it mimics Western Jackdaw, Common Magpie, European Bee-eater, Common Blackbird, White Wagtail, Common Tern, Common Reed Bunting, Great Tit, Black-headed Gull, Common House Martin, Fieldfare, European Greenfinch, Black woodpecker, Yellow Wagtail. The extended song versions have also been suggested as being plastic song, see the discussion in [Forum discussion 16491](http://www.xeno-canto.org/forum/topic/16491)

SNR ≤59dB

recordings.file-name: XC256109-Whitethroat song with imitation, Carnalea,5 July 2014; 0700hrs.mp3
recordings.rmk: This songster is, probably, the same individual that features in XC256108. Certainly, just one male was present in a limited area from the date of the above recording (28 April 2014) to this one (5 July 2014). Interesting, therefore, to detect quite different forms in the two recordings. In XC256108 the phrases are longer and some are almost rambling. In this recording each song burst is, in a manner of speaking, tightly edited and all four bursts come across as fairly similar. Listen more closely and at the end of the first, second and fourth (final) burst you can hear a terminal note that strongly resembles a Chaffinch 'chwink'. The third burst in the series (commencing at 0:09) lacks the Chaffinch-like note. Chaffinches were breeding nearby so the Whitethroat would have heard calling birds regularly. According to published literature, Whitethroats are occasionally mimics. In the background, Eiders can be heard calling within the first second of the recording.

Song from a fairly recently arrived male. This bird continued to sing in the same area - a narrow strip of coastal scrub that held just one pair of Whitethroats - until the middle of July. The bursts are typical of the species: fast  and scratchy volatile outpourings which defy a handy description. In fact, this male's bursts are quite variable. For example, although most deliveries are from two seconds to five seconds in length, that from 0:19 lasts for eight seconds. Background species include a pair of Grey Wagtails (breeding nearby) at 0:08 and single calls from one of the pair at 0:15 and 0:16. A Common Sandpiper can be heard at 0:26 and 0:43.

Probably the same individual remained in the area and bred. Over two months later - on 5 July 2014 - another recording was made of the song. That recording is XC256109. In comparison to XC256108, the July song bursts are shorter and more succinct. Further discussion of the two recordings are detailed at XC256109.
Alarm calls of a female Whitethroat leading fledged immatures through some thornbushes on the banks of the rhine. Recording Equipment: Sennheiser ME 67, Sound devices 702
Alarm calls of a female Whitethroat leading fledged immatures through some thornbushes on the banks of the river Rhine. Recording Equipment: Sennheiser ME 67, Sound devices 702
